subject: Re: [junit] assert keywork
msgSnippet: You should enable assert keyword in java compiler as well as in JRE. Java Compiler: In window- preference- Java- Compiler- Compliance and Classfiles, set all
messageBody:
You should enable assert keyword in java compiler as well as in JRE.
Java Compiler: In window->preference->Java->Compiler->Compliance and
Classfiles, set all levels to 1.4
JRE: Just as Benedict Heal said"window/preferences/java/installed
JREs, edit the JRE, and set the vmargs to -ea"

Also, if you only want to enable assert keyword in several projects,
you can set the project's preference and "Run..." preference.
Java Compiler: In Project->Preference->Java->Compiler->Compliance
and Classfiles.
JRE: Run->Run..., select your junit case and then in Arguments->VM
Arguments add -ea.



On Mon, 08 Nov 2004 16:42:13 +0100, Filip S. Adamsen
<filip@...> wrote:
>
> Shouldn't you be using one of the assert* methods instead of the Java
> keyword, or do you have a reason not to?
>
> -Filip
>
>
>
> albamatiit wrote:
> >
> >
> > I use JUnit in Eclipse 3.0. When an assert (java keyword) fail, the
> > test go on instead of terminate with an error. How can I detect an
> > assert failure in tests?
> > Bye
> > Alberto
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
